49298862-26667.title: API reference

49298862-26670.title: Return value from superValidate

49298862-26673.title: Server API

49298862-26676.title: superValidate(data, schema, options?)

49298862-26679.title: setError(form, field, error, options?)
49298862-26679.content:
setError(
  form: Validation<T, M>,
  field: keyof S | [keyof S, ...(string | number)[]] | [] | null,
  error: string | string[],
  options?: { overwrite = false, status = 400 }
) : ActionFailure<{form: Validation<T, M>}>
```

For setting errors on the form after validation. It returns a `fail(status, { form })` so it can be returned immediately, or more errors can be added by calling it multiple times before returning. 

Use the `overwrite` option to remove all previously set errors for the field, and `status` to set a different status than the default `400`.

If the `field` argument is set to an empty array or `null`, the error will be a form-level error that can be accessed on the client with `$errors._errors`.

49298862-26682.title: message(form, message, options?)

49298862-26685.title: noErrors(form)
49298862-26685.content:
If you want to return a form with no validation errors. Only the `errors` property will be modified, so `valid` still indicates the validation status. Can be useful for load functions where the entity is invalid, but as an initial state no errors should be displayed on the form.

noErrors(form: Validation<T, M>) : Validation<T, M>
```

49298862-26688.title: actionResult(type, data?, status?)

49298862-26700.title: intProxy(form, fieldName)
49298862-26700.content: Creates a proxy store for an integer schema field. Changes in either the proxy store or the form field will reflect in the other.

49298862-26703.title: numberProxy(form, fieldName)
49298862-26703.content: Creates a proxy store for a numeric form field.

49298862-26706.title: booleanProxy(form, fieldName, options?)

49298862-26709.title: dateProxy(form, fieldName, options?)

Data is assumed to be async but can also load non-async data using await block!statusBoolean`true`Whether to show or hide status code.stringTruncateNumber`120`Truncate long string in output.refHTMLPreElement`undefined`Binds pre tag to ref.

49298862-27301.title: Contributing
49298862-27301.content:
Contributions to Superforms are very welcome! The issues and discussion pages on Github are always open for comments, and if you want to contribute some code, it's quite easy. Just fork either the Superforms repository or its website, then you just need to execute the following to be up and running:

npm install
npm run dev
```

pnpm install
pnpm dev
```

If you find a typo on the website, you can make a quick PR directly in its Github repository.

49298862-27304.title: Sponsoring
49298862-27304.content: I'm doing my very best to provide super support on Discord and Github to everyone who needs help, and also to keep improving the library and this website. If you want to contribute a small sum towards that, it's greatly appreciated, knowing that someone wants to see this project improve and live on.

49298862-27307.title: Voting on new features
49298862-27307.content: You can give a thumbs up on the Github issues marked with "enhancement", and I will prioritize the most popular ones for the next feature release.

49298862-27390.title: Designing a CRUD interface
49298862-27390.content:
An excellent use case for Superforms is a backend interface, commonly used as in the acronym CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete):

Display an empty formDisplay an empty formPOST the form, validate the dataPOST the form, validate the dataCreate a new entity with the data **(Create)**Create a new entity with the data (Create)Fetch the entity **(Read)**Fetch the entity (Read)Display it in a formDisplay it in a formPOST the form, validate the dataPOST the form, validate the dataUpdate the entity with the data **(Update)**Update the entity with the data (Update)Delete the entity **(Delete)**Delete the entity (Delete)??????Profit!Profit!

Because you can send the data model to the `superValidate` function and have the form directly populated, it becomes quite easy to implement the above steps.

49298862-27393.title: Getting started
49298862-27393.content:
To follow along, there are two ways:

1. The easy wayOpen the Stackblitz repo and you're up and running in the browser in 15 seconds!

2. The slightly harder wayStart from scratch in a new SvelteKit project, by executing one of the following commands in your project directory:

npm create svelte@latest
```

pnpm create svelte@latest
```

Select Skeleton project and Typescript syntax at the prompts, the rest is up to you. Then add this to `<head>` in src/app.html for a much nicer visual experience:

<link
  rel="stylesheet"
  href="https://unpkg.com/normalize.css@8.0.1/normalize.css" />
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://unpkg.com/sakura.css/css/sakura.css" />
```

49298862-27405.title: Creating and Updating a user

49298862-27408.title: Deleting a user

49298862-27411.title: Listing the users

49298862-27757.title: Default values
49298862-27757.content:
When `superValidate` encounters a schema field that isn't optional, or when a `FormData` field is empty, a default value is returned to the form, to ensure that the type is correct:

typevaluestring`""`number`0`boolean`false`Array`[]`object`{}`bigint`BigInt(0)`symbol`Symbol()`This behavior of returning empty values can be turned off if you pass `options.implicitDefaults = false` to `superValidate`, which means that you must add `default` to all required fields of your schema.

49298862-27760.title: Changing a default value

49298862-27763.title: Non-supported defaults

49298862-27911.title: Flash messages
49298862-27911.content:
Status messages are useful, but redirects will cause them to be lost, because they need to be returned in `{ form }`, usually as a response from a POST request.

Since it's common to redirect after a successful post, especially in backend interfaces, the `form.message` property isn't a general solution for displaying status messages.

The sister library to Superforms is called sveltekit-flash-message, a useful addon that handles temporary messages sent with redirects. Follow the installation and configuration instructions at its repo, then you can add it to Superforms, and it will work without any extra calls to `updateFlash`.

49298862-27914.title: Usage

49298862-27917.title: syncFlashMessage
49298862-27917.content: If set to `true`, the flash message will be synchronized with `form.message`.

49298862-27920.title: flashMessage.onError
49298862-27920.content: The flash message is set automatically for every `ActionResult` except `error`, so the `onError` callback is needed to transform errors into your flash message type, or leave it out to disregard them.

49298862-27960.title: Flash messages
49298862-27960.content:

Since it's common to redirect after a successful post, especially in backend interfaces, the `form.message` property isn't a general solution for displaying status messages.

The sister library to Superforms is called sveltekit-flash-message, a useful addon that handles temporary messages sent with redirects. Follow the installation and configuration instructions at its repo, then you can add it to Superforms, and it will work without any extra calls to `updateFlash`.

49298862-27963.title: Usage

49298862-27969.title: flashMessage.onError

49298862-27970.title: Superforms playground
49298862-27970.content:
If you have gone through the Concepts section of this site, maybe you want to test out some things. The easiest way to do that is to use this Stackblitz repo:

https://stackblitz.com/edit/sveltekit-superforms-testing

It gives you a starting point that you can use for experimenting, bug reporting or more advanced support questions.

49298862-27990.title: Installation
49298862-27990.content:
Install Superforms with `npm` or `pnpm`:

npm i -D sveltekit-superforms zod
```

pnpm i -D sveltekit-superforms zod
```

49298862-27993.title: Following along
49298862-27993.content:
The easiest way is to open the Stackblitz project for this tutorial.

Otherwise, you can create a new SvelteKit project with `npm create svelte@latest` and copy/paste the code as you go along, or add it to an existing project.

49298862-27996.title: Creating a Superform
49298862-27996.content: Let's gradually build up a Superform containing a name and an email address.

49298862-27999.title: Creating a validation schema

49298862-28002.title: Initializing the form in the load function

49298862-28005.title: Important note about return values
49298862-28005.content: At the end of the load function we return `{ form }`. You should always return the validation object to the client in this manner, either directly or through a helper function. The name of the variable doesn't matter, you can call it `{ loginForm }` or anything else, but it needs to be returned in all code paths, both in load functions and form actions, encapsulated in an object.

49298862-28008.title: Displaying the form
49298862-28008.content:
Now when we have sent the validation data to the client, we will retrieve it using the client part of the API: src/routes/+page.svelte
``` `superForm` is used on the client to display the data, that we just sent from the server in `data.form`. This is what the form should look like now:

49298862-28011.title: Debugging
49298862-28011.content:
Now we can see that the form is populated. But to get deeper insight, let's add the Superform Debugging Svelte Component called `SuperDebug`:

src/routes/+page.svelte

<script lang="ts">
  import SuperDebug from 'sveltekit-superforms/client/SuperDebug.svelte';
</script>

<SuperDebug data={$form} />
```

This should be displayed:

Edit the form fields and see how the data is automatically updated. The component also displays the current page status in the right corner.

49298862-28014.title: Posting data

49298862-28017.title: Displaying errors

49298862-28020.title: Next steps
49298862-28020.content:
This concludes the tutorial, but you'd probably want to enable client-side functionality, to take full advantage of the features and enhancements that Superforms bring.

To do that, take a look at use:enhance under the Concepts section in the navigation. Most pages there contain interactive examples that helps you use the library to its fullest.

When you've gone over all the concepts, check the API reference for a full list of properties returned from `superForm`, and all options that you can use.

If you're ready for a more advanced tutorial, check out Designing a CRUD interface, which shows how to make a fully working backend in about 150 lines of code.

49298862-28190.title: Superforms playground

49298862-28193.title: Client-side validation
49298862-28193.content: There is already a web standard for client-side form validation, which is virtually effortless to use with Superforms. For more advanced cases, you can use either a Zod schema or the built-in validation object for an exhaustive client-side validation.

49298862-28196.title: Usage

49298862-28199.title: constraints
49298862-28199.content:
To use the web standard constraints, simply spread the `$constraints` store for a field on its input field:

<input
  name="email"
  type="email"
  bind:value={$form.email}
  {...$constraints.email} />
```

The constraints is an object with validation properties mapped from the schema:

{
  pattern?: string;      // z.string().regex(r)
  step?: number;         // z.number().step(n)
  minlength?: number;    // z.string().min(n)
  maxlength?: number;    // z.string().max(n)
  min?: number | string; // number if z.number.min(n), ISO date string if z.date().min(d)
  max?: number | string; // number if z.number.max(n), ISO date string if z.date().max(d)
  required?: true;       // Not nullable, nullish or optional
}
```

49298862-28202.title: validators

49298862-28205.title: defaultValidator
49298862-28205.content:
There is one additional option for specifying the `on:input` behavior for fields with errors:

defaultValidator: 'keep' | 'clear' = 'keep'
```

The default value `keep` means that validation errors will be displayed until the form submits (and is set to clear errors). `clear` will remove the error as soon as that field value is modified.

In a future version, the `validators` will be run `on:input` as well.

49298862-28208.title: Test it out
49298862-28208.content: This example demonstrates how validators are used to check if tags are of the correct length. It uses `defaultValidator = 'clear'` to remove the error when the field changes.

49298862-28263.title: Client-side validation
49298862-28263.content: There is already a web standard for client-side form validation, which is virtually effortless to use with Superforms. For more advanced cases, you can use either a Zod schema or the built-in validation object for an exhaustive client-side validation.

49298862-28266.title: Usage

49298862-28269.title: constraints
49298862-28269.content:
To use the web standard constraints, simply spread the `$constraints` store for a field on its input field:

<input
  name="email"
  type="email"
  bind:value={$form.email}
  {...$constraints.email} />
```

The constraints is an object with validation properties mapped from the schema:

{
  pattern?: string;      // z.string().regex(r)
  step?: number;         // z.number().step(n)
  minlength?: number;    // z.string().min(n)
  maxlength?: number;    // z.string().max(n)
  min?: number | string; // number if z.number.min(n), ISO date string if z.date().min(d)
  max?: number | string; // number if z.number.max(n), ISO date string if z.date().max(d)
  required?: true;       // Not nullable, nullish or optional
}
```

49298862-28272.title: validators

49298862-28275.title: defaultValidator
49298862-28275.content:
There is one additional option for specifying the `on:input` behavior for fields with errors:

defaultValidator: 'keep' | 'clear' = 'keep'
```

The default value `keep` means that validation errors will be displayed until the form submits (and is set to clear errors). `clear` will remove the error as soon as that field value is modified.

In a future version, the `validators` will be run `on:input` as well.

49298862-28278.title: Test it out
49298862-28278.content: This example demonstrates how validators are used to check if tags are of the correct length. It uses `defaultValidator = 'clear'` to remove the error when the field changes.

49298862-28279.title: Progressive enhancement
49298862-28279.content:
By using `enhance` returned from `superForm` on a form, we'll get the client-side enhancement expected from a modern webpage:

<script lang="ts">
  const { form, enhance } = superForm(data.form);
  //            ^^^^^^^
</script>

<form method="POST" use:enhance>
```

Now all form submissions will happen on the client, and we unlock a ton of extra features, that will be explained here and in the rest of this section.

As a general rule, without `use:enhance` on the form, not much will work. You'll get no events, no timers, no client-side validation except for `constraints`, etc.

49298862-28282.title: Usage

49298862-28285.title: applyAction
49298862-28285.content:
When `applyAction` is `true` the form will have the default SvelteKit behavior of updating and reacting on `$page.form` and `$page.status`, and also redirecting automatically.

Turning this behavior off can be useful when you want to isolate the form from other sources updating the page, for example Supabase events. Read more about what happens when `applyAction` is applied in the SvelteKit docs.

49298862-28288.title: invalidateAll
49298862-28288.content: When `invalidateAll` is `true` and a successful validation result is returned from the server, the page will be invalidated and the load function will run.

49298862-28291.title: resetForm
49298862-28291.content: Since we're binding the fields to `$form`, a html form reset (clearing all fields in DOM) won't have any effect, so in Superforms, resetting means going back to the initial state of the form data, which usually is the form data in `PageData`. This may not be exactly what you want, in which case you can use an event to clear the form instead.

49298862-28294.title: When to change the defaults?
49298862-28294.content:
Quite rarely! If you have a single form on the page and nothing else is causing the page to invalidate, you'll probably be fine as it is. 

For multiple forms on the same page, use `options.id` to prevent forms from reacting on `$page`, instead of setting `applyAction` to `false`, though if you have events triggered that will invalidate the page, it may be the solution.

49298862-28297.title: Differences from SvelteKit's use:enhance
49298862-28297.content:
The biggest difference is that any ActionResult with status `error` is transformed into `failure` to avoid form data loss, since when the nearest `+error.svelte` page is rendered, it will wipe out the form and all data that was just entered.

The onError event is a more user-friendly way of handling server errors.

As described above, the form isn't resetted by default either. This should be opt-in to avoid data loss, and isn't always wanted, especially in backend interfaces, where the form data should be kept after updating. For manual resets, you can use the `reset` method returned from `superForm`.

49298862-28366.title: Progressive enhancement
49298862-28366.content:
By using `enhance` returned from `superForm` on a form, we'll get the client-side enhancement expected from a modern webpage:

<script lang="ts">
  const { form, enhance } = superForm(data.form);
  //            ^^^^^^^
</script>

<form method="POST" use:enhance>
```

Now all form submissions will happen on the client, and we unlock a ton of extra features, that will be explained here and in the rest of this section.

As a general rule, without `use:enhance` on the form, not much will work. You'll get no events, no timers, no client-side validation except for `constraints`, etc.

49298862-28369.title: Usage

49298862-28372.title: applyAction
49298862-28372.content:
When `applyAction` is `true` the form will have the default SvelteKit behavior of updating and reacting on `$page.form` and `$page.status`, and also redirecting automatically.

Turning this behavior off can be useful when you want to isolate the form from other sources updating the page, for example Supabase events. Read more about what happens when `applyAction` is applied in the SvelteKit docs.

49298862-28375.title: invalidateAll
49298862-28375.content: When `invalidateAll` is `true` and a successful validation result is returned from the server, the page will be invalidated and the load function will run.

49298862-28378.title: resetForm
49298862-28378.content: Since we're binding the fields to `$form`, a html form reset (clearing all fields in DOM) won't have any effect, so in Superforms, resetting means going back to the initial state of the form data, which usually is the form data in `PageData`. This may not be exactly what you want, in which case you can use an event to clear the form instead.

49298862-28381.title: When to change the defaults?
49298862-28381.content:
Quite rarely! If you have a single form on the page and nothing else is causing the page to invalidate, you'll probably be fine as it is. 

For multiple forms on the same page, use `options.id` to prevent forms from reacting on `$page`, instead of setting `applyAction` to `false`, though if you have events triggered that will invalidate the page, it may be the solution.

49298862-28384.title: Differences from SvelteKit's use:enhance
49298862-28384.content:
The biggest difference is that any ActionResult with status `error` is transformed into `failure` to avoid form data loss, since when the nearest `+error.svelte` page is rendered, it will wipe out the form and all data that was just entered.

The onError event is a more user-friendly way of handling server errors.

As described above, the form isn't resetted by default either. This should be opt-in to avoid data loss, and isn't always wanted, especially in backend interfaces, where the form data should be kept after updating. For manual resets, you can use the `reset` method returned from `superForm`.

49298862-28385.title: Error handling
49298862-28385.content: Most errors will be set automatically through the validation schema, but you may want to add errors after determining that the data is valid. This is easily done with the `setError` helper function.

49298862-28388.title: setError

49298862-28391.title: Usage (client)
49298862-28391.content:
On the client, errors are available in the `$errors` store. It gives you a high flexibility, since you can place error messages anywhere on the page. But there are more to errors than just displaying them.

On larger forms the submit button may be far away from the error. Then it's nice showing the user where the first error is. There are a couple of options for that:

const { form, enhance, errors, allErrors } = superForm(data.form, {
  scrollToError: 'smooth' | 'auto' | 'off' = 'smooth'
  autoFocusOnError: boolean | 'detect' = 'detect'
  errorSelector: string | undefined = '[data-invalid]'
  stickyNavbar: string | undefined = undefined
})
```

49298862-28394.title: scrollToError
49298862-28394.content: The `scrollToError` options determines how to scroll to the first error message in the form. `smooth` and `auto` are values from Window.scroll().

49298862-28397.title: autoFocusOnError
49298862-28397.content: When `autoFocusOnError` is set to its default value `detect`, it checks if the user is on a mobile device, if not it will automatically focus on the first error input field. It's prevented on mobile since auto-focusing will open the on-screen keyboard, most likely hiding the validation error.

49298862-28400.title: errorSelector
49298862-28400.content:
This is the selector used to find the invalid input fields. The default is `[data-invalid]`, and the first one found on the page will be handled according to the two previous settings. You usually set it on the input fields as such:

<input
  type="email"
  name="email"
  bind:value={$form.email}
  data-invalid={$errors.email} />
```

49298862-28403.title: stickyNavbar
49298862-28403.content: If you have a sticky navbar, set its selector here and it won't hide any errors due to its height and z-index.

49298862-28406.title: Form-level errors

49298862-28409.title: Listing errors

49298862-28412.title: Test it out
49298862-28412.content: This form has `data-invalid` set on erroneous fields, and lists all errors on top of the form using `$allErrors`. Try to submit and see that the first error field gets focus automatically, unless on mobile.

49298862-28482.title: Error handling
49298862-28482.content: Most errors will be set automatically through the validation schema, but you may want to add errors after determining that the data is valid. This is easily done with the `setError` helper function.

49298862-28485.title: setError

49298862-28488.title: Usage (client)
49298862-28488.content:
On the client, errors are available in the `$errors` store. It gives you a high flexibility, since you can place error messages anywhere on the page. But there are more to errors than just displaying them.

On larger forms the submit button may be far away from the error. Then it's nice showing the user where the first error is. There are a couple of options for that:

const { form, enhance, errors, allErrors } = superForm(data.form, {
  scrollToError: 'smooth' | 'auto' | 'off' = 'smooth'
  autoFocusOnError: boolean | 'detect' = 'detect'
  errorSelector: string | undefined = '[data-invalid]'
  stickyNavbar: string | undefined = undefined
})
```

49298862-28491.title: scrollToError
49298862-28491.content: The `scrollToError` options determines how to scroll to the first error message in the form. `smooth` and `auto` are values from Window.scroll().

49298862-28494.title: autoFocusOnError
49298862-28494.content: When `autoFocusOnError` is set to its default value `detect`, it checks if the user is on a mobile device, if not it will automatically focus on the first error input field. It's prevented on mobile since auto-focusing will open the on-screen keyboard, most likely hiding the validation error.

49298862-28497.title: errorSelector
49298862-28497.content:
This is the selector used to find the invalid input fields. The default is `[data-invalid]`, and the first one found on the page will be handled according to the two previous settings. You usually set it on the input fields as such:

<input
  type="email"
  name="email"
  bind:value={$form.email}
  data-invalid={$errors.email} />
```

49298862-28500.title: stickyNavbar
49298862-28500.content: If you have a sticky navbar, set its selector here and it won't hide any errors due to its height and z-index.

49298862-28503.title: Form-level errors

49298862-28506.title: Listing errors

49298862-28509.title: Test it out
49298862-28509.content: This form has `data-invalid` set on erroneous fields, and lists all errors on top of the form using `$allErrors`. Try to submit and see that the first error field gets focus automatically, unless on mobile.

49298862-28510.title: Events
49298862-28510.content: With `use:enhance` enabled, you get full control over the form submit process through a number of events.

49298862-28513.title: Event flowchart
49298862-28513.content: Click on the event you want to know more about!

49298862-28516.title: Usage
49298862-28516.content:
const { form } = superForm(data.form, {
  onSubmit: ({ action, data, form, controller, cancel }) => void
  onResult: ({ result, formEl, cancel }) => void
  onUpdate: ({ form, cancel }) => void
  onUpdated: ({ form }) => void
  onError: (({ result, message }) => void) | 'apply'
})
```

49298862-28519.title: onSubmit

49298862-28522.title: onResult

49298862-28525.title: onUpdate
49298862-28525.content:
onUpdate: ({ form, cancel }) => void
```

If you don't care about the specifics of the `ActionResult`, rather the validation result itself, `onUpdate` is triggered just before the form update is being applied, and gives you the option to modify the validation result in `form`, or `cancel()` the update altogether.

49298862-28528.title: onUpdated

49298862-28531.title: onError
49298862-28531.content:
onError: (({ result, message }) => void) | 'apply'
```

Finally, the `onError` event allows you to act on `ActionResult` errors. You can use its `message` store parameter to set it to the error value here.

By setting onError to `apply`, the default `applyAction` behaviour will be used, effectively rendering the nearest `+error` boundary (and wiping out the form, so be careful).

Tip: If you're unsure what event to use, start with `onUpdated`.

49298862-28569.title: Events
49298862-28569.content: With `use:enhance` enabled, you get full control over the form submit process through a number of events.

49298862-28572.title: Event flowchart
49298862-28572.content: Click on the event you want to know more about!

49298862-28575.title: Usage
49298862-28575.content:
const { form } = superForm(data.form, {
  onSubmit: ({ action, data, form, controller, cancel }) => void
  onResult: ({ result, formEl, cancel }) => void
  onUpdate: ({ form, cancel }) => void
  onUpdated: ({ form }) => void
  onError: (({ result, message }) => void) | 'apply'
})
```

49298862-28578.title: onSubmit

49298862-28581.title: onResult

49298862-28584.title: onUpdate
49298862-28584.content:
onUpdate: ({ form, cancel }) => void
```

If you don't care about the specifics of the `ActionResult`, rather the validation result itself, `onUpdate` is triggered just before the form update is being applied, and gives you the option to modify the validation result in `form`, or `cancel()` the update altogether.

49298862-28587.title: onUpdated

49298862-28590.title: onError
49298862-28590.content:
onError: (({ result, message }) => void) | 'apply'
```

Finally, the `onError` event allows you to act on `ActionResult` errors. You can use its `message` store parameter to set it to the error value here.

By setting onError to `apply`, the default `applyAction` behaviour will be used, effectively rendering the nearest `+error` boundary (and wiping out the form, so be careful).

Tip: If you're unsure what event to use, start with `onUpdated`.

49298862-28591.title: Status messages
49298862-28591.content:
So far, almost every feature has been on the client! That's where the action is, but you may have noticed that a status message like "Form posted" is displayed when submitting the forms in the examples.

The validation object contains a `message` property that is used for this.

49298862-28594.title: Usage

49298862-28597.title: The message helper

49298862-28600.title: Strongly typed message

49298862-28603.title: Event handling in non-JS settings
49298862-28603.content: Events aren't available unless JavaScript and `use:enhance` is enabled. But you can use the message as a simple event handler in non-JS scenarios. Its existence means that the form was submitted, and you can decorate it with extra metadata.

49298862-28606.title: Limitations
49298862-28606.content:
Naturally, redirects will cause the message to be lost. Since it's common to redirect after a successful post, the `message` property isn't a general solution for displaying status messages.

The library sveltekit-flash-message is a complete solution that works with redirects however. It can be directly integrated into superforms, documented here.

49298862-28640.title: Status messages
49298862-28640.content:
So far, almost every feature has been on the client! That's where the action is, but you may have noticed that a status message like "Form posted" is displayed when submitting the forms in the examples.

The validation object contains a `message` property that is used for this.

49298862-28643.title: Usage

49298862-28646.title: The message helper

49298862-28649.title: Strongly typed message

49298862-28652.title: Event handling in non-JS settings
49298862-28652.content: Events aren't available unless JavaScript and `use:enhance` is enabled. But you can use the message as a simple event handler in non-JS scenarios. Its existence means that the form was submitted, and you can decorate it with extra metadata.

49298862-28655.title: Limitations
49298862-28655.content:
Naturally, redirects will cause the message to be lost. Since it's common to redirect after a successful post, the `message` property isn't a general solution for displaying status messages.

The library sveltekit-flash-message is a complete solution that works with redirects however. It can be directly integrated into superforms, documented here.

49298862-28656.title: Multiple forms
49298862-28656.content:
Since there is only one `$page.form` per page, having multiple forms, for example a register and login form on the same page, can cause trouble since an update with the built-in `use:enhance` will affect both forms.

Fortunately Superforms has a solution for this! Multiple forms on the same page are possible by setting `options.id` for each form (one can have the default id, `undefined`). This prevents them from interfering with with each other, which can happen since they all update the same `$page.status` and `$page.form`.

49298862-28659.title: Usage

49298862-28662.title: Server-client communication
49298862-28662.content:
This is only the server-to-client part however. You can still post to this form action from anywhere, and the server knows nothing about who sent the form.

This may work with the example above, a login form that probably is the only form that posts to its form action or endpoint. But for more dynamic scenarios, let's say a database table where rows can be editable, you want to communicate to the server which form id was sent.

This could be as simple as using named form actions, or in a more dynamic fashion, using a hidden form field or a query parameter, to let the server know what `id` was posting.

49298862-28665.title: Setting id on the client

49298862-28668.title: Test it out

49298862-28707.title: Multiple forms
49298862-28707.content:
Since there is only one `$page.form` per page, having multiple forms, for example a register and login form on the same page, can cause trouble since an update with the built-in `use:enhance` will affect both forms.

Fortunately Superforms has a solution for this! Multiple forms on the same page are possible by setting `options.id` for each form (one can have the default id, `undefined`). This prevents them from interfering with with each other, which can happen since they all update the same `$page.status` and `$page.form`.

49298862-28710.title: Usage

49298862-28713.title: Server-client communication
49298862-28713.content:
This is only the server-to-client part however. You can still post to this form action from anywhere, and the server knows nothing about who sent the form.

This may work with the example above, a login form that probably is the only form that posts to its form action or endpoint. But for more dynamic scenarios, let's say a database table where rows can be editable, you want to communicate to the server which form id was sent.

This could be as simple as using named form actions, or in a more dynamic fashion, using a hidden form field or a query parameter, to let the server know what `id` was posting.

49298862-28716.title: Setting id on the client

49298862-28719.title: Test it out

49298862-28720.title: Nested data
49298862-28720.content: Html forms are inherently one-dimensional, in the sense that the input fields can only handle string values. There is no built-in way to represent a nested data structure or more complex values like dates. But this can be handled by Superforms!

49298862-28723.title: Usage

49298862-28726.title: dataType
49298862-28726.content:
By simply setting `dataType` to `json`, you can store any data structure allowed by devalue in the form, and you don't have to worry about failed coercion, converting arrays to strings and back, etc! You don't even have to set names for the form fields anymore, since the data in the `$form` store is now posted, not the fields in the html. They are now merely UI components for the data.

As a precaution, `superForm` will try to detect nested objects, and if found, an error is thrown unless `dataType = 'json'`.

49298862-28729.title: Requirements
49298862-28729.content:
The requirement for this however, is that

**JavaScript is enabled in the browser**JavaScript is enabled in the browser**The form has use:enhance applied.**The form has use:enhance applied.

49298862-28732.title: Nested errors and constraints
49298862-28732.content:
When your schema contains arrays or objects, you can access them through the `$form` as an ordinary object. But how does it work with errors and constraints?

`$errors` and `$constraints` actually mirrors the `$form` data, but with every field or "leaf" in the object replaced with `string[]` and `InputConstraints` respectively.

49298862-28735.title: Example

49298862-28738.title: An exception: Primitive arrays
49298862-28738.content: Since you can post multiple html elements with the same name, you don't have to use `dataType = 'json'` for arrays of primitive values like numbers and strings. Just add the input fields, Superforms will handle the type coercion to array automatically.

49298862-28781.title: Nested data
49298862-28781.content: Html forms are inherently one-dimensional, in the sense that the input fields can only handle string values. There is no built-in way to represent a nested data structure or more complex values like dates. But this can be handled by Superforms!

49298862-28784.title: Usage

49298862-28787.title: dataType
49298862-28787.content:
By simply setting `dataType` to `json`, you can store any data structure allowed by devalue in the form, and you don't have to worry about failed coercion, converting arrays to strings and back, etc! You don't even have to set names for the form fields anymore, since the data in the `$form` store is now posted, not the fields in the html. They are now merely UI components for the data.

As a precaution, `superForm` will try to detect nested objects, and if found, an error is thrown unless `dataType = 'json'`.

49298862-28790.title: Requirements
49298862-28790.content:
The requirement for this however, is that

**JavaScript is enabled in the browser**JavaScript is enabled in the browser**The form has use:enhance applied.**The form has use:enhance applied.

49298862-28793.title: Nested errors and constraints
49298862-28793.content:
When your schema contains arrays or objects, you can access them through the `$form` as an ordinary object. But how does it work with errors and constraints?

`$errors` and `$constraints` actually mirrors the `$form` data, but with every field or "leaf" in the object replaced with `string[]` and `InputConstraints` respectively.

49298862-28796.title: Example

49298862-28799.title: An exception: Primitive arrays
49298862-28799.content: Since you can post multiple html elements with the same name, you don't have to use `dataType = 'json'` for arrays of primitive values like numbers and strings. Just add the input fields, Superforms will handle the type coercion to array automatically.

49298862-28800.title: Proxy objects
49298862-28800.content: Sometimes the form data must be proxied, which could happen when you get a `string` value from an input field, third-party library, etc, and want it to be automatically converted and updating a non-string value in your form data structure. Fortunately, there are a number of objects available for that:

49298862-28803.title: Usage

49298862-28806.title: intProxy(form, fieldName)
49298862-28806.content: Creates a proxy (store) for an integer in the schema. Changes in either the proxy or the form field will reflect in the other.

49298862-28809.title: numberProxy(form, fieldName)
49298862-28809.content: Creates a proxy (store) for a number in the schema.

49298862-28812.title: booleanProxy(form, fieldName, options?)

49298862-28815.title: dateProxy(form, fieldName, options?)

49298862-28818.title: Usage

49298862-28821.title: Test it out
49298862-28821.content: Change the value of the date picker to see it reflect in the date field of the schema. We're also taking advantage of the `min` constraint to automatically limit the date selection to current and future dates only.

49298862-28835.title: Proxy objects
49298862-28835.content: Sometimes the form data must be proxied, which could happen when you get a `string` value from an input field, third-party library, etc, and want it to be automatically converted and updating a non-string value in your form data structure. Fortunately, there are a number of objects available for that:

49298862-28838.title: Usage

49298862-28841.title: intProxy(form, fieldName)
49298862-28841.content: Creates a proxy (store) for an integer in the schema. Changes in either the proxy or the form field will reflect in the other.

49298862-28844.title: numberProxy(form, fieldName)
49298862-28844.content: Creates a proxy (store) for a number in the schema.

49298862-28847.title: booleanProxy(form, fieldName, options?)

49298862-28850.title: dateProxy(form, fieldName, options?)

49298862-28853.title: Usage

49298862-28856.title: Test it out
49298862-28856.content: Change the value of the date picker to see it reflect in the date field of the schema. We're also taking advantage of the `min` constraint to automatically limit the date selection to current and future dates only.

49298862-28857.title: Snapshots
49298862-28857.content: A quite recent SvelteKit feature is snapshots, which saves and restores data when the user navigates in the browser history. This is perfect for saving the form state, and with Superforms you can take advantage of this in one line of code.

49298862-28860.title: Usage

49298862-28863.title: Test it out
49298862-28863.content: Modify the form below without submitting, then click the browser back button and then forward again. The form should be restored to its intermediate state. (`taintedMessage` is set to `null` for this example.)

49298862-28874.title: Snapshots
49298862-28874.content: A quite recent SvelteKit feature is snapshots, which saves and restores data when the user navigates in the browser history. This is perfect for saving the form state, and with Superforms you can take advantage of this in one line of code.

49298862-28877.title: Usage

49298862-28880.title: Test it out
49298862-28880.content: Modify the form below without submitting, then click the browser back button and then forward again. The form should be restored to its intermediate state. (`taintedMessage` is set to `null` for this example.)

49298862-28881.title: Submit behavior
49298862-28881.content: Making the user understand that things are happening when they submit the form is imperative for the best possible user experience. Superforms provides you with timers (see next section) and the following option for handling this:

49298862-28884.title: Usage

49298862-28887.title: clearOnSubmit
49298862-28887.content:
The `clearOnSubmit` option decides what should happen to the form when submitting. It can clear all the `errors`, the `message`, both or none. The default is to clear both.

If you don't want any jumping content, which could occur when error messages are removed from the DOM, setting it to one of the other options can be useful.

49298862-28890.title: multipleSubmits
49298862-28890.content:
This one is as much for the sake of the server than of the user.

When set to `prevent`, the form cannot be submitted again until a result is received, or the `timeout` state is reached (see next section).When set to `prevent`, the form cannot be submitted again until a result is received, or the `timeout` state is reached (see next section).`abort` is the next sensible approach, which will cancel the previous request before submitting again.`abort` is the next sensible approach, which will cancel the previous request before submitting again.Finally, `allow` will pass through any number of frenetic clicks on the submit button!Finally, `allow` will pass through any number of frenetic clicks on the submit button!

49298862-28927.title: Submit behavior
49298862-28927.content: Making the user understand that things are happening when they submit the form is imperative for the best possible user experience. Superforms provides you with timers (see next section) and the following option for handling this:

49298862-28930.title: Usage

49298862-28933.title: clearOnSubmit
49298862-28933.content:
The `clearOnSubmit` option decides what should happen to the form when submitting. It can clear all the `errors`, the `message`, both or none. The default is to clear both.

If you don't want any jumping content, which could occur when error messages are removed from the DOM, setting it to one of the other options can be useful.

49298862-28936.title: multipleSubmits
49298862-28936.content:
This one is as much for the sake of the server than of the user.

When set to `prevent`, the form cannot be submitted again until a result is received, or the `timeout` state is reached (see next section).When set to `prevent`, the form cannot be submitted again until a result is received, or the `timeout` state is reached (see next section).`abort` is the next sensible approach, which will cancel the previous request before submitting again.`abort` is the next sensible approach, which will cancel the previous request before submitting again.Finally, `allow` will pass through any number of frenetic clicks on the submit button!Finally, `allow` will pass through any number of frenetic clicks on the submit button!

49298862-28937.title: Tainted form check
49298862-28937.content: When a form field is modified, that field, and in turn the form, is considered tainted. A Superforms feature is to prevent the user from losing data, by accidentaly navigating away from a tainted form.

49298862-28940.title: Usage

49298862-28943.title: Tainted store
49298862-28943.content: You can access the exact fields that are tainted through the `$tainted` store, returned from `superForm`. When you modify the form fields above you'll see how the `$tainted` store reacts.

49298862-28946.title: Untainting the form
49298862-28946.content:
When a validation result is returned for the form with a status between `200-299`, the form is automatically marked as untainted by setting the `$tainted` store to `undefined`.

Try that by posting the form with valid values. The tainted message should not appear when browsing away from the page.

49298862-28949.title: Disabling the check
49298862-28949.content: By setting `taintedMessage = null` in the options, the form won't be checked for modifications.

49298862-28979.title: Tainted form check
49298862-28979.content: When a form field is modified, that field, and in turn the form, is considered tainted. A Superforms feature is to prevent the user from losing data, by accidentaly navigating away from a tainted form.

49298862-28982.title: Usage

49298862-28985.title: Tainted store
49298862-28985.content: You can access the exact fields that are tainted through the `$tainted` store, returned from `superForm`. When you modify the form fields above you'll see how the `$tainted` store reacts.

49298862-28988.title: Untainting the form
49298862-28988.content:
When a validation result is returned for the form with a status between `200-299`, the form is automatically marked as untainted by setting the `$tainted` store to `undefined`.

Try that by posting the form with valid values. The tainted message should not appear when browsing away from the page.

49298862-28991.title: Disabling the check
49298862-28991.content: By setting `taintedMessage = null` in the options, the form won't be checked for modifications.

49298862-28992.title: Timers
49298862-28992.content: As said in the previous section, the user should understand that things are happening when they submit the form. Timers gives us a way of providing feedback at the right time, based upon human perception research.

49298862-28995.title: Usage

49298862-28998.title: Submit state
49298862-28998.content:
The `delayMs` and `timeoutMs` decides how long before the submission changes state. The states are:

These states affect the readable stores `submitting`, `delayed` and `timeout` returned from `superForm`. They are not mutually exclusive, so `submitting` won't change to `false` when `delayed` becomes `true`.

49298862-29001.title: Loading indicators
49298862-29001.content:
A perfect use for these timers is to show a loading indicator while the form is submitting: src/routes/+page.svelte
{#if $delayed}Working...{/if}
``` The reason for using `delayed` instead of `submitting` is based on the article Response Times: The 3 Important Limits, which states that for short waiting periods, no feedback is required except to display the result. Therefore, `delayed` is used to show a loading indicator after a little while.

49298862-29004.title: Visualizing the timers
49298862-29004.content:
Try submitting this form and see how different delay times affect the timers. Loading spinners are set to display when `delayed` and `timeout` are true. The request itself is set to timeout with an error after 10 seconds.

Click multiple times to see the effect of `multipleSubmits = 'prevent'` as well.

Experimenting with these three timers and the delay between them, it's certainly possible to prevent the feeling of unresponsiveness in many cases. Please share your results on Discord or Github, if you do!
